title: Patriots have 15 players land on injury report, but get some good news
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Fifteen Patriots players are on the injury report ahead of their Thursday game against the Jets.
Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson were limited participants on Monday after missing Sunday's game.
Austin Hooper missed Monday's walk-through due to a concussion, adding to the team's injury concerns.

title: Georgia man allegedly stole millions in unclaimed Mass. property
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Shaka Stayman, 44, of Atlanta, accused of stealing millions in unclaimed Massachusetts property, pleaded not guilty in Suffolk Superior Court.
Stayman allegedly filed seven fraudulent claims, receiving $1.1 million and attempting to claim an additional $2.2 million.
He allegedly used false documents and ghost phone numbers to reroute checks; held on $2 million cash bail.

title: TreVeyon Henderson explained why he looked at the sideline during key TD run
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: TreVeyon Henderson scored a key touchdown for the Patriots despite uncertainty on clock strategy during the final minutes.
Henderson looked to the sideline for guidance, but ultimately decided to score, sealing a decisive win over Tampa Bay.
With Rhamondre Stevenson out, Henderson has increased his role, achieving a career-best performance with over 100 yards.

title: Mason Lohrei is latest Bruins player to respond from a Marco Sturm benching
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Mason Lohrei returned to the Boston Bruins lineup against Toronto, recording two assists and playing a pivotal role in the win.
Lohrei's comeback followed a five-game benching due to defensive struggles under coach Marco Sturm's decision.
Coach Marco Sturm's strategy saw other players like Casey Mittelstadt and Marat Khusnutdinov improve after lineup removals this season.

title: Petitioners gathering signatures to repeal legal marijuana accused of misleading voters
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Petitioners in Massachusetts accused of misleading voters while gathering signatures to repeal recreational marijuana.
Complaints received about signature gatherers allegedly misrepresenting the petition to voters, according to state officials.
Massachusetts Cannabis Business Association accuses signature efforts of 'organized voter fraud' due to misleading practices.

title: Massachusetts state payroll hits $9B in 2025 â€” UMass system dominates
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Massachusetts state payroll reached $9.19 billion in 2025, decreasing from 2024's $10.26 billion.
All top 15 highest-paid state employees are from UMass, with Frank Martin earning $1,955,216.
UMass system accounted for $1.55 billion in payroll, while MBTA and Trial Court had $799.68M and $574.67M respectively.

title: Mass. State Police: 56 arrested in three-day child exploitation sweep
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Massachusetts State Police's 'Operation Firewall' resulted in 56 arrests linked to child exploitation in a three-day sweep.
Authorities seized 229 electronic devices and executed 34 search warrants, uncovering large quantities of illegal material.
The suspects included individuals with various backgrounds, emphasizing the lack of a specific profile for such offenders.

title: 5 ways to help fight food insecurity in the North Shore right now
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: SNAP benefits restored amid the government shutdown; over 1 million in Massachusetts impacted by previous cuts.
Volunteer opportunities at Beverly Bootstraps, The Salem Pantry, and La Colaborativa support local food distribution.
Donations accepted by Lynn Community Fridge and sponsored meals at The Open Door to combat food insecurity.

title: SNAP fully funded, Healey says, as she urges residents to use benefits
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Gov. Maura Healey confirms SNAP benefits are fully funded in Massachusetts and urges residents to use their benefits.
A federal judge blocked the Trump administration's attempt to claw back already issued SNAP benefits amid the government shutdown.
Healey and Attorney General Andrea Campbell take legal action to secure SNAP funding against federal directives during the shutdown.

title: Falmouth to vote on turning historic golf course into solar farm
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Falmouth to vote on transforming historic Cape Cod Country Club into solar farm and conservation area on Nov. 17.
Project could install 45,000 solar panels over 57 acres, generating 29,000 megawatt-hours annually for Barnstable County.
Plans include donating 137 acres for conservation, with opposition from residents citing historical significance and housing needs.
